title: Why do people hate One Direction and Justin Bieber? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Why do people hate One Direction and Justin Bieber?” I usually don’t answer questions like this one because people tend to be hypersensitive about it. To begin, there’s an old saying in Latin: De gustibus non est disputandum. It means that you can’t argue with taste. What people like and dislike is personal. If you can figure out what you like about music from One Direction and Justin Bieber, you will also know a lot about what other people don’t like about them. I thought Krishnabh Medhi’s answer was pretty good, but here’s a little more. A lot of work has been done to quantify music, especially measures like meter, pitch, timbre, and loudness. If you were to quantify these metrics, you should find that popular music is highly conventional and stable over long periods of time. Less formally, most people can sing popular music, albeit with varying degrees of success. Pitch transitions are an important part of that, which is why early music instruction emphasizes reproduction of patterns like Do-Mi-So. Pop music also has a homogeneous timbral palette. That’s a bit technical, but you can easily look those terms up. What it means is that popular music tends to be simple and predictable. In turn, that means that you can write music mechanically. For example, check out: Algorithmic composition It’s easier than it seems. For example, let’s say you started out with a million rabbits, you made them all run, and you picked the fastest half. The statistical distribution of the faster rabbits won’t look as random as the whole population did. If you do that again and again, the distribution of the remaining rabbits will look similar to the first time you did it, and of course the rabbits will be getting better and better. Music has gone through the same sort of process. That is, the music that our ancestors liked got copied. The music they didn’t like, didn’t. Eventually, you get music that is closer and closer to perfect in the sense that it reliably gets the same emotional reaction from the sort of person that likes that particular kind of music. In this context, “perfect” does not mean that you and I will like the same music. Our taste is personal and individual. When people say that music is ‘popular’ they mean that a lot of people like it, but it would not be less perfect if only one person did. By the way, your brain processes the emotional value of a note of music at the almost unbelievable speed of 250 microseconds. That’s too fast to think about it. You either have the emotional reaction, or you don’t. If you were to take a survey, and there are many informal surveys available online, you would find a recurring pattern. For example, over 70% of people like McDonald's french fries or Kraft mac & cheese. About 1 or 2 in 10 will say that it is their favorite. By that standard, the 4th movement of Beethoven's 9th symphony is about as good as Lady Gaga's Poker Face. The music a given person likes says a great deal about how close his or her ear is to a conventional sort of middle ground. The end of Beethoven's 9th is popular because it is conventional, loud, and slow, and because it has a simple, repetitive melody that people can hum or sing along with, one which Phillip Hale (1899) referred to as "...the unspeakable cheapness of the chief tune..." The bottom line is that you shouldn’t spend too much time thinking about what music other people like. The only thing that matters is whether you like it. As I said at the beginning, if you can figure out what you like about a particular song, you also know a lot about what other people don’t like about it. In the case of Beethoven’s 9th symphony, someone who doesn’t like it might describe it as conventional, predictable, and repetitive. That is, if you like it and they don’t, there’s a good chance that that’s for exactly the same reasons. Weird, huh? That’s a lot to think about, I know, but I hope you will think about it, at least a little. If there’s one thing I hope you’ll take away from it, it is just this: Music is good because you like it, not the other way around. A lot of people make themselves miserable trying to like music that other people say is ‘good,’ or ‘better.’ Listen to music you like, but remember to stay open to possibility. Music is amazing. It’s one of our very best things.
